questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a nonpruritic, painless rash on his face for 5 days. His 62-year-old maternal grandmother has bullous pemphigoid. His development is adequate for his age and immunizations are up-to-date. He appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F) and pulse is 90/min. Examination shows a nontender rash just inferior to the lower lip. A photograph of the patient's face is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical betamethasone therapy is indicated in the treatment of allergic contact dermatitis (ACD). The rash in ACD usually manifests as erythematous, papular vesicles with serous oozing. The distribution pattern of the rash reflects the areas and shapes of external exposure, e.g., a rash appearing where jewelry is usually worn if nickel is the allergen. In contrast to this patient's rash, the lesions in ACD are intensely pruritic.
Image Description:

An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.

This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

B) INCORRECT:

Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparations of skin scrapings are used to diagnose superficial skin infections by dermatophytes such as Trichophyton rubrum, which can cause facial tinea. Facial tinea presents as round or oval, red, scaly lesions that often have a central clearing, not with lesions that are crusted over. Additionally, tinea often causes pruritus, whereas this patient has no such symptoms.
Image Description:

Left lateral view of a patient's face and neck

Multiple, partially crusted erythematous plaques with well-defined margins are visible on this patients cheek and neck.

These skin lesions are suggestive of an infection with dermatophytes (most likely T. verrucosum and T. mentagrophytes) and diagnosis should be confirmed by microscopy and culture in order to definitively determine the type of dermatophytes.

C) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes virus infections. Herpes labialis presents as multiple vesicles on an erythematous base that may ulcerate and form a crust. However, unlike this patient's rash, the outbreak of the herpetic lesions is usually preceded by tingling, burning, and/or pain over the affected skin. In children without a history of prior episodes, the primary infection with herpes simplex virus 1 typically manifests as gingivostomatitis, rather than facial lesions.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles on an erythematous base can be seen on the lower lip.

This is the characteristic appearance of herpes labialis.

D) INCORRECT:

Systemic antibiotic therapy (e.g., with clindamycin) can be used for the treatment of bullous impetigo, ecthyma, and severe nonbullous impetigo, whereas this patient has only mild impetigo. Additionally, dicloxacillin would be preferred over clindamycin for systemic antibiotic therapy, unless methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is suspected as a causative organism.

E) INCORRECT:

Miconazole is used topically in the treatment of superficial fungal infections such as tinea. Facial tinea manifests as round or oval, red, scaly lesions that often have a central clearing, which is different from the crusted-over lesions in this patient. Additionally, tinea often causes pruritus, whereas this patient has no such symptoms.
Image Description:

Localization: chest
Lesion: local, round, eczematous lesion that grows centrifugally with pustules and scaling

F) INCORRECT:

Systemic antibiotic therapy (usually with cephalexin or dicloxacillin) is indicated in the treatment of bullous impetigo, severe nonbullous impetigo, and ecthyma. The absence of bullae in this patient rules out the diagnosis of bullous impetigo. Patients with ecthyma present with heaped-up, dry crusts that are tightly adherent to the skin instead of amber-colored pus-filled crusts. In the case of ecthyma, extremities are also more commonly affected than the face. This patient has mild nonbullous impetigo, which requires different management.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles, some of which have already ruptured and formed brown crusts, are visible on the gluteal region of this infant. The lesions in bullous impetigo are easily confused with the polymorphic rash of secondary syphilis.

G) INCORRECT:

A skin biopsy may be indicated for blistering disorders of the skin such as bullous pemphigoid (BP) when the diagnosis is unclear. Although the patient could have a genetic predisposition for blistering skin disease, given the history of BP in his maternal grandmother, the disease rarely occurs during childhood. However, most important, BP would manifest with bullae. Moreover, the lesions typical of BP would have brown rather than yellow crusts and would usually be concentrated on the trunk rather than the face.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.

H) CORRECT:

Nonbullous impetigo is the most common type of impetigo and manifests with papular and/or pustular lesions with serous oozing that dry and form characteristic honey-colored crusts. Although these lesions typically develop on the face, they may also affect the extremities. Nonbullous impetigo is typically a clinical diagnosis (see “Most common manifestations of impetigo” table). A skin culture may be necessary for patients with persistent, recurrent infection or if the diagnosis is inconclusive. Topical antibiotics such as mupirocin and retapamulin are the first-line treatment for mild nonbullous impetigo. In patients with multiple lesions or ecthyma, systemic antibiotics may be required.

I) INCORRECT:

Swabs of pus or detritus from the patient's skin lesions can be used for Gram stain and culture. This is only performed if clinical findings are inconclusive or if treatment is ineffective. In the latter case, Gram stain and culture can detect the causative pathogen and its resistance pattern. This is especially relevant in cases of infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, which requires more tailored antibiotic therapy with clindamycin. Performing routine swabs for all patients is not indicated in the case of impetigo.
questions.hint: This patient's painless, nonpruritic, honey-colored crusts (without vesicles) located on the chin are consistent with nonbullous impetigo, which is usually due to infection with Staphylococcus aureus and sometimes group A streptococci.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-day history of a pruritic skin rash on his chest. He has a history of atopic dermatitis but is otherwise healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date and he takes no medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 102/62 mm Hg. Examination of the chest shows multiple vesicles and flaccid bullae that contain clear, yellow fluid, as well as ruptured bullae that are surrounded by thin brown crusts. Examination of the oral mucosa shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although erythema multiforme (EM) may manifest with pruritic skin lesions, the skin findings are characteristically of variable morphology (erythematous macules, papules, vesicles, target lesions with central necrosis). Moreover, the rash first affects the back of the hands and feet before spreading proximally to the rest of the body. Finally, EM is most common in adults 20–40 years of age and is usually associated with infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and/or the use of medications (e.g., barbiturates, NSAIDs, phenytoin).
Image Description:

Trunk and right arm of an infant

Multiple erythematous macules are visible, arranged in concentric rings with a pale center and an outer erythematous margin. The macules are partly confluent and of different sizes.

These lesions are suggestive of erythema multiforme, a hypersensitivity reaction that can be caused by various infections (most commonly herpes simplex virus infections), certain drugs, or immune dysregulation.

B) CORRECT:

Bullous impetigo (BI) is characterized by vesicles that grow to form large flaccid bullae filled with clear yellow fluid, which rupture and form thin brown crusts, predominantly on the trunk and upper extremities. BI is caused by the exfoliative toxin A produced by S. aureus and is mostly seen in children 2–6 years of age. In severe cases, toxins and bacteria released into the blood system may cause fever in addition to the typical skin findings. Predisposing factors for BI include warm and humid climates, unsanitary living conditions, poor personal hygiene, disruption of the skin barrier (e.g., due to trauma or diseases such as scabies or atopic dermatitis), and immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection). First-line treatment options include oral antibiotic treatment with first-generation cephalosporins (e.g, cephalexin) and dicloxacillin. A very rare but life-threatening complication of BI is staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which is characterized by systemic spread of exfoliative toxin A and the resultant widespread desquamation of epidermal skin and signs of shock.

See “Overview of blistering diseases” table.

Nonbullous impetigo may be caused by Staphylococcus aureus and/or Streptococcus pyogenes and typically manifests with painless, nonpruritic, honey-colored crusts without bullae (see “Most common manifestations of impetigo” table).
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles, some of which have already ruptured and formed brown crusts, are visible on the gluteal region of this infant. The lesions in bullous impetigo are easily confused with the polymorphic rash of secondary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) is characterized by areas of pruritic excoriations and vesicles that affect the extensor surfaces of the knees, elbows, buttocks, and back. This patient's bullae and crusts manifest on his chest. Moreover, DH is uncommon in children and is typically associated with celiac disease.
Image Description:

There is an erythematous, grouped, papulovesicular rash with excoriations on the extensor surface of the shoulder.

This finding, in combination with pruritus, is consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) can manifest with a pruritic vesiculobullous rash and may involve any part of the body, including the trunk. SJS can develop at any age. However, most patients develop targetoid lesions and present with mucosal involvement (e.g., oral and/or genital ulcers, conjunctivitis), and cutaneous manifestations are typically preceded by prodromal symptoms (e.g., high fever, malaise, sore throat). Moreover, most cases of SJS are caused by medication use (e.g., sulfonamides, allopurinol, lamotrigine) or infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae, cytomegalovirus, HSV).
Image Description:

Widespread mucocutaneous necrosis with patches of complete epidermal destruction and involvement of the lips are visible.

These findings are suggestive for the SJS, which is triggered by pharmacological treatment (e.g., with antibiotics, antiepileptics).

E) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) can manifest with large pruritic bullae that eventually rupture and form crusts. However, the bullae in BP are tense rather than flaccid and are typically distributed on the palms, soles, lower legs, groin, and axillae, not the chest. In addition, BP has a prodromal stage characterized by urticarial lesions that occurs weeks to months before blistering. Lastly, although in rare cases BP can develop in children, it most commonly manifests in individuals > 60 years of age.
Image Description:

Lateral aspect of the left knee

Multiple, ring-shaped lesions with reddish-yellow crusting and tense blisters on an erythematous base are visible.

These findings are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Definitive diagnosis requires immunofluorescence.

F) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) can manifest with flaccid bullae filled with clear fluid on the upper body that can rupture and form crusts. However, blisters in PV are nonpruritic and usually first develop on the oral mucosa. Although PV can develop in children, it most commonly affects individuals aged 40–60 years.
Image Description:

Scalp of an older adult

An ulcerated lesion (approx. 1–2 cm) with significant crusting around the irregular border is visible. The center of the lesion is eroded and shows a shiny surface with mild hemorrhage.

These findings are consistent with skin lesions in pemphigus vulgaris.
questions.hint: This patient has a very common and highly contagious pediatric skin disease, which is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 4-day history of irritability and a rash. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F). Examination of the skin shows multiple vesicles, flaccid transparent bullae that contain clear yellow fluid, and brown crusts on her chest and upper extremities. Application of a shear force to surrounding unaffected skin does not cause sloughing. Examination of the oral mucosa shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The production of antidesmoglein antibodies is the pathomechanism behind pemphigus vulgaris (PV), a blistering skin condition characterized by painful, flaccid, intraepidermal bullae on the upper body that rupture to form erosions and crusts. PV, however, typically first develops on the oral mucosa, and a positive Nikolsky sign is usually present. In addition, PV most commonly affects individuals 40–60 years of age.
Image Description:

Flaccid bullae and gray-white plaques are visible on the oral mucosa. The plaque can be scraped off, causing deep red erosions.

These findings are consistent with pemphigus vulgaris.

B) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a rare cutaneous type IV hypersensitivity reaction that manifests with a vesiculobullous rash and may involve any part of the body, including the trunk. SJS can develop at any age. However, most patients develop targetoid lesions and present with mucosal involvement (e.g., oral and/or genital ulcers, conjunctivitis), and cutaneous manifestations are typically preceded by prodromal symptoms (e.g., high fever, malaise, sore throat). The Nikolsky sign is also typically positive in patients with SJS. Moreover, most cases of SJS are caused by medication use (e.g., sulfonamides, allopurinol, lamotrigine) or infections (e.g., Mycoplasma pneumoniae, cytomegalovirus, HSV).
Image Description:

Back, buttocks, thighs, and legs of an 8-month-old infant 2 weeks after primary vaccination

Irregularly shaped, partially confluent, erythematous macules with bullae are visible.

Patient history suggests Stevens-Johnson syndrome triggered by vaccination.

C) CORRECT:

Exfoliative toxin A is the most common cause of bullous impetigo (BI). Released by specific pathogenic strains of Staphylococcus aureus, exfoliative toxin A cleaves the desmosomal proteins responsible for keeping keratinocytes bound to one another in the stratum granulosum. Loss of these connections results in vesicles that grow to form large flaccid bullae filled with clear yellow fluid, which rupture and form thin brown crusts, predominantly on the trunk and upper extremities. The Nikolsky sign is negative. The release of toxins and bacteria into the blood may cause fever in addition to the typical skin findings. BI is mostly seen in children 2–6 years of age. Predisposing factors include warm and humid climates, unsanitary living conditions, poor personal hygiene, disruption of the skin barrier (e.g., due to trauma or diseases such as scabies or atopic dermatitis), and immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection). A very rare but life-threatening complication of BI is staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which is characterized by systemic spread of exfoliative toxin A and the resultant widespread desquamation of epidermal skin, a positive Nikolsky sign, and signs of shock.

See “Overview of blistering diseases” table.
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles, some of which have already ruptured and formed brown crusts, are visible on the gluteal region of this infant. The lesions in bullous impetigo are easily confused with the polymorphic rash of secondary syphilis.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with Streptococcus pyogenes can manifest as nonbullous impetigo, which is characterized by papules that first develop into small vesicles surrounded by erythema, and later, pustules. Thick, honey-colored crusts form when vesicles and pustules rupture. Lesions are usually localized and mostly occur on the face (especially the mouth and nose), but may also be found on the extremities. The Nikolsky sign is negative. However, bullae are not a feature of nonbullous impetigo (see “Most common manifestations of impetigo” table).
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

E) INCORRECT:

The production of IgG antihemidesmosome antibodies is the pathomechanism behind bullous pemphigoid (BP), which manifests as subepidermal bullae and has a negative Nikolsky sign. However, the bullae in BP are tense rather than flaccid and are typically distributed on the palms, soles, lower legs, groin, and axillae, not the chest. In addition, BP has a prodromal stage characterized by urticarial lesions that occur weeks to months before blistering. Lastly, although in rare cases BP can develop in children, it most commonly manifests in individuals > 60 years of age.
Image Description:

Tense blisters, erosions, and crusts on erythematous skin are visible on the knee.

These findings are consistent with bullous pemphigoid.
questions.hint: The age of the patient and presence of flaccid, transparent bullae filled with clear yellow fluid, together with a negative Nikolsky sign (skin does not slough off when a shear force is applied), are consistent with bullous impetigo.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a nonpruritic rash on his face that began 5 days ago. It started as a bug bite on his chin that then developed into small pustules with surrounding redness. He has not yet received any routine childhood vaccinations. Physical examination shows small, clustered lesions with gold crusts along the lower lip and chin and submandibular lymphadenopathy. At a follow-up examination 2 weeks later, his serum anti-deoxyribonuclease B antibody titer is elevated. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a severe systemic inflammatory reaction to bacterial exotoxins acting as superantigens. S. aureus is the most common causative agent, although streptococcal TSS may occur in the setting of infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococci. Although both pathogens can cause impetigo, TSS is an exceedingly rare complication. Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome is most commonly associated with prolonged tampon use (over several days) and, to a lesser extent, post-surgical or wound infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Rheumatic fever is a noninfectious, inflammatory sequela of untreated acute tonsillopharyngitis caused by group A streptococci. It is thought to be due to a cross-reaction of antibodies (molecular mimicry). The resulting type 2 hypersensitivity reaction then causes injury of the heart, skin, joints, and nerves. Streptococcal skin infections including impetigo have not been shown to lead to rheumatic fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis is a rare, immune-mediated condition that manifests with a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis 1–4 weeks after an enteric or genitourinary bacterial infection. It typically occurs in genetically predisposed young adults and is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Group A streptococcal infections such as impetigo are not known to trigger reactive arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Shingles is caused by a reactivation of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals after a primary VZV infection (i.e., chickenpox). Chickenpox presents with a highly pruritic rash that classically appear in different stages (from vesicles to crusts) and that covers the entire body. Although the lack of vaccinations puts this child at risk for VZV infection, his presentation and elevated anti-DNase B antibody titer are inconsistent with chickenpox.
Image Description:

Upper body of a young boy with exanthem showing the simultaneous occurrence of various stages of rash; mainly vesicles and pustules, no crusted erosions. This clinical finding is also referred to as "starry sky" and is typical of chickenpox.

E) CORRECT:

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a common complication of impetigo and may occur in response to an infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci. It is caused by immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane, which triggers complement activation and subsequent destruction of the glomeruli (type III hypersensitivity reaction). PSGN typically arises 1–6 weeks following infection, with features of nephritic syndrome, such as hematuria, edema, and hypertension.

Further complications of group A streptococcal infections include rheumatic fever and scarlet fever. Although scarlet fever occurs in very rare cases after streptococcal skin infections such as impetigo, both conditions are typically only associated with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

F) INCORRECT:

Orchitis is a typical complication of viral mumps infection. Given the lack of vaccinations, this child is at increased risk of contracting mumps. However, mumps classically manifests with inflammation and swelling of the salivary glands and is not associated with a rash. However, orchitis is not a known complication of infections with S. aureus or group A streptococci such as impetigo.
Image Description:

There is significant symmetrical neck swelling due to swelling of the salivary glands and lymph nodes.

G) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis is a complication of infection with toxin-producing strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Diphtheria initially manifests with fever, malaise, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy, but cutaneous manifestations such as nonhealing sores may also be seen. Although this child's lack of vaccinations puts him at risk for infection with C. diphtheriae, his presentation and elevated anti-DNase B antibody titer are inconsistent with diphtheria.
Image Description:

A gray-white pseudomembrane extends from the left palatine tonsil over the uvula to the hard palate. The pseudomembrane consists of fibrinous exudate as well as immune and epithelial cells and is characteristic of tonsillar and pharyngeal diphtheria.
questions.hint: This child's gold-crusted facial lesions are consistent with impetigo, a cutaneous infection that may be caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes, or coinfection with both pathogens. The elevated anti-deoxyribonuclease B (anti-DNase B) antibody titer indicates that the causal pathogen was S. pyogenes.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents with a facial rash that developed abruptly during the past 48 hours and has been slightly tender to the touch. The patient has been afebrile and has no associated systemic symptoms. He has no significant medical history and no recent unusual exposures.
Skin examination reveals multiple moist erythematous lesions on the face with overlying crust (figure); no vesicles or bullous lesions are evident. The rest of the examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a systemic glucocorticoid that is not indicated in cases of superficial skin infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is indicated for cases of herpetic infection. Although a herpetic infection could also manifest with honey-colored crusting, the crust usually overlies erythematous papules or papulovesicles in a group array.

C) INCORRECT:

The systemic antibiotic doxycycline is not indicated for an immunocompetent patient with limited impetigo. Indications for systemic antibiotic therapy in impetigo include immunosuppression, extensive skin involvement, bullous disease, and membership in a cohort with multiple affected individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

Terbinafine cream treats superficial dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea faciei) and is ineffective for impetigo. The classic manifestation of tinea faciei is an annular scaly erythematous plaque.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s rash — characterized by localized areas of honey-colored crusting that is loosely adhered to the face — is highly characteristic of impetigo, a contagious, bacterial infection of the superficial epidermis. Impetigo is often spread in warm, humid environments or in close, crowded quarters. The lesions of impetigo may begin as papules and progress over several days to form vesicles, pustules, and eventually a characteristic layer of adherent, golden crust. The crust usually involves the face, extremities, or both and can be itchy or painful.

Other common causes of honey-colored crusting include herpes viral infections and allergic contact dermatitis. Like impetigo, both of these conditions can also manifest with vesicles and bullae. Bacterial and viral cultures — or polymerase-chain-reaction testing for herpes simplex virus or varicella zoster virus — should be performed in cases of diagnostic uncertainty. In this patient, the absence of grouped vesicles makes herpetic disease unlikely. The location and distribution of lesions are also less concerning for herpetic infection; herpes simplex viral infection typically affects the lips, oropharynx, peri-oral area, and (infrequently) the nares, whereas varicella-zoster virus infection would manifest in a dermatomal pattern. Allergic contact dermatitis is less likely than impetigo in this patient given his lack of recent unusual exposures.

For an immunocompetent individual with limited impetigo, first-line treatment consists of a topical antibiotic ointment that provides coverage for both Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes. Coverage of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) should be strongly considered for patients who live in areas with high rates of community-acquired MRSA. Topical mupirocin and retapamulin both offer staphylococcal and streptococcal coverage and are widely used as first-line agents for impetigo. Other topical antibiotics, such as clindamycin, provide only staphylococcal coverage. Topical disinfectants alone do not provide adequate treatment. Additional recommended skin-care measures include gentle removal of the crusting with soap and a washcloth.

Key learning point: First-line treatment for a limited area of nonbullous impetigo in an immunocompetent individual consists of topical antibiotic ointment.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought in for evaluation of a facial rash that has been worsening during the past week. Her father reports that the rash began at her left nostril with small bumps and spread up her nose with some visible pus. He reports that the bumps have since broken down into a yellowish crust. Multiple children in the girl’s day camp have had similar rashes in the past 2 weeks.
On examination, there is a thick, gold-colored, adherent crust overlying an erythematous base around and within both nostrils (figure). The area is tender to palpation.
Which one of the following treatments is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: An ointment containing bacitracin, neomycin, and polymyxin B

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Over-the-counter triple antimicrobial ointments have some activity against staphylococcal and streptococcal species but are less effective than mupirocin or retapamulin. Some individuals may also develop a contact dermatitis reaction to neomycin and/or bacitracin.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral cephalexin is likely to cover both group A streptococcus and MSSA, but it would not cover MRSA. Furthermore, it is unnecessary as a first-line regimen in this patient, whose isolated lesions are likely to be managed just as effectively with topical therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Increasing resistance has made oral macrolide therapy (e.g., azithromycin) relatively ineffective against both S. aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes. Because the use of azithromycin for patients infected with macrolide-resistant strains is likely to result in organism persistence and subsequent risk for development of rheumatic fever (in the case of streptococcal infections), azithromycin is not recommended as first-line therapy for skin and soft-tissue infections, and its use in this setting should be limited to patients who have a documented history of anaphylactic reactions to penicillin.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin would be effective against group A streptococcus but ineffective against S. aureus because of beta-lactamase production by most S. aureus strains.

E) CORRECT:

Nonbullous impetigo is a contagious, superficial bacterial infection of the skin. It is often spread in warm, humid environments or in close, crowded quarters. The lesions of impetigo begin as papules and progress over several days to form pustules and eventually a characteristic layer of thick, adherent, golden crust. Impetigo can occur anywhere on the body where there has been bacterial inoculation by staphylococcal or streptococcal organisms; in children, it is common on the face and around the nose. When it occurs in isolation on otherwise healthy skin (versus in the context of impetiginized eczema), it is often tender or painful rather than itchy.

Antimicrobial therapy for impetigo should be directed against the two most common causative organisms: Staphylococcus aureus (both methicillin-susceptible [MSSA] and methicillin-resistant [MRSA]) and group A streptococcus. Nonbullous lesions isolated to a small area can be treated effectively with a topical agent such as mupirocin or retapamulin. Of note, bacterial culture may be an important step in diagnosis and management, especially given the prevalence of antibiotic-resistant strains. Ideally, bacterial culture is obtained at initial presentation in patients who are at high risk for infection with resistant strains (such as MRSA), patients who live in areas with a high prevalence of such strains, and patients who fail to respond to initial empiric therapy. Antibiotic selection is then directed according to the culture results.

Key learning point: The best initial antimicrobial therapy for children with isolated nonbullous impetigo is a topical antibiotic such as mupirocin or retapamulin.

questions.text:
A 3-week-old boy presents for evaluation of a rash that has been evident for 2 days in his diaper area and lower abdomen. He seems tired but does not appear to be ill. His rectal temperature is 38°C, and he has normal vital signs.
Examination reveals multiple scattered bullae, measuring 2 to 8 cm, in the diaper area and lower abdomen. Some bullae are intact with yellow fluid collecting in the inferior (dependent) aspect of the bulla, while other lesions consist of a collarette of scale at the periphery of a ruptured blister (figure).
What is the most likely pathogenesis of the findings described in this infant?

choices.text: Impaired skin-barrier function with abnormal transepidermal water loss
Bacterial production of exfoliative toxin A, resulting in loss of cell adhesion in the dermis
Bacterial production of exfoliative toxin A, resulting in loss of cell adhesion in the superficial epidermis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis is an inflammatory dermatitis resulting from genetically impaired skin-barrier function with abnormal transepidermal water loss. It manifests as weepy patches and scaly, intensely pruritic plaques, typically on the cheeks, trunk, and extensor extremities of infants. It does not manifest as vesicles or bullae unless secondarily infected or in cases of an associated allergic contact dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bullous impetigo is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus exfoliative toxin A and loss of cell adhesion in the superficial epidermis, not the dermis.

C) INCORRECT:

Varicella (chicken pox) is an acute infectious disease caused by varicella-zoster virus. Preceded by viremia, varicella manifests as a generalized, pruritic rash that commonly starts on the head followed by the trunk and extremities. The individual lesions progress rapidly from macules to papules to vesicles before crusting. During the vesicular phase, the lesions appear as clear fluid-filled vesicles on an erythematous base (“dew drops on a rose petal”). A patient will often have lesions in various stages of evolution — pink to red macules, papules, intact vesicles, and crusts.

D) CORRECT:

Bullous impetigo most commonly affects neonates but may also affect older children and adults. It is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus exfoliative toxin A and loss of cell adhesion in the superficial epidermis.

The rash in bullous impetigo starts as superficial vesicles that progress to rapidly enlarging, flaccid bullae with sharp margins and surrounding erythema. The bullae rupture easily, usually within 1 to 3 days; therefore, intact bullae are rare on examination. If they are intact, there may be a characteristic “fluid level” within, with yellowish purulence noted in the dependent portion of the blister. After rupturing, the bullae drain a cloudy yellow fluid (pus) and leave the pathognomonic collarette of scale. The bullous lesions favor moist, intertriginous areas, such as the diaper area and axillae. Associated systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, generalized weakness, and diarrhea are not common but can be present in infants.

In nonbullous impetigo, the most common form of impetigo, the lesions are not bullae but instead appear as oozy patches and plaques with characteristic cloudy, honey-colored crusts that result from dried purulent discharge. The lesions are most commonly found on the face and extremities, can be tender or pruritic, and may be associated with regional lymphadenopathy.

Ecthyma, often associated with Streptococcus pyogenes, is a form of impetigo characterized by ulcerative, punched-out lesions with yellow crusts surrounded by raised, violaceous margins extending deep into the dermis.

Key learning point: Bullous impetigo is most commonly caused by bacterial production of exfoliative toxin A and loss of cell adhesion in the superficial epidermis.

E) INCORRECT:

Stevens-Johnson syndrome is a severe mucocutaneous reaction most commonly triggered by infections or medications. It is characterized by massive keratinocyte necrosis and detachment of the epidermis. Although bullae may appear, they would occur over dusky, necrotic skin and would not feature pus.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents with a facial rash that developed abruptly during the past 48 hours and has been slightly tender to the touch. The patient has been afebrile and has no associated systemic symptoms. He has no significant medical history and no recent unusual exposures.
Skin examination reveals multiple moist erythematous lesions on the face with overlying crust (figure); no vesicles or bullous lesions are evident. The rest of the examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Terbinafine cream treats superficial dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea faciei) and is ineffective for impetigo. The classic manifestation of tinea faciei is an annular scaly erythematous plaque.

B) CORRECT:

This patient’s rash — characterized by localized areas of honey-colored crusting that is loosely adhered to the face — is highly characteristic of impetigo, a contagious, bacterial infection of the superficial epidermis. Impetigo is often spread in warm, humid environments or in close, crowded quarters. The lesions of impetigo may begin as papules and progress over several days to form vesicles, pustules, and eventually a characteristic layer of adherent, golden crust. The crust usually involves the face, extremities, or both and can be itchy or painful.

Other common causes of honey-colored crusting include herpes viral infections and allergic contact dermatitis. Like impetigo, both of these conditions can also manifest with vesicles and bullae. Bacterial and viral cultures — or polymerase-chain-reaction testing for herpes simplex virus or varicella zoster virus — should be performed in cases of diagnostic uncertainty. In this patient, the absence of grouped vesicles makes herpetic disease unlikely. The location and distribution of lesions are also less concerning for herpetic infection; herpes simplex viral infection typically affects the lips, oropharynx, peri-oral area, and (infrequently) the nares, whereas varicella-zoster virus infection would manifest in a dermatomal pattern. Allergic contact dermatitis is less likely than impetigo in this patient given his lack of recent unusual exposures.

For an immunocompetent individual with limited impetigo, first-line treatment consists of a topical antibiotic ointment that provides coverage for both Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes. Coverage of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) should be strongly considered for patients who live in areas with high rates of community-acquired MRSA. Topical mupirocin and retapamulin both offer staphylococcal and streptococcal coverage and are widely used as first-line agents for impetigo. Other topical antibiotics, such as clindamycin, provide only staphylococcal coverage. Topical disinfectants alone do not provide adequate treatment. Additional recommended skin-care measures include gentle removal of the crusting with soap and a washcloth.

Key learning point: First-line treatment for a limited area of nonbullous impetigo in an immunocompetent individual consists of topical antibiotic ointment.

C) INCORRECT:

The systemic antibiotic doxycycline is not indicated for an immunocompetent patient with limited impetigo. Indications for systemic antibiotic therapy in impetigo include immunosuppression, extensive skin involvement, bullous disease, and membership in a cohort with multiple affected individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a systemic glucocorticoid that is not indicated in cases of superficial skin infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is indicated for cases of herpetic infection. Although a herpetic infection could also manifest with honey-colored crusting, the crust usually overlies erythematous papules or papulovesicles in a group array.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a 3-day history of a pruritic skin rash on his chest. Examination of the chest shows multiple vesicles and flaccid bullae that contain clear, yellow fluid, as well as ruptured bullae that are surrounded by thin brown crusts. Examination of the oral mucosa shows no abnormalities. Results of a complete blood count are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although erythema multiforme (EM) may manifest with pruritic skin lesions, the skin findings are characteristically of variable morphology (erythematous macules, papules, vesicles, target lesions with central necrosis). Moreover, the rash first affects the back of the hands and feet before spreading proximally to the rest of the body. Finally, EM is most common in adults 20–40 years of age and is usually associated with infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and/or the use of medications (e.g., barbiturates, NSAIDs, phenytoin).
Image Description:

Trunk and right arm of an infant

Multiple erythematous macules are visible, arranged in concentric rings with a pale center and an outer erythematous margin. The macules are partly confluent and of different sizes.

These lesions are suggestive of erythema multiforme, a hypersensitivity reaction that can be caused by various infections (most commonly herpes simplex virus infections), certain drugs, or immune dysregulation.

B) CORRECT:

Bullous impetigo (BI) is characterized by vesicles that grow to form large flaccid bullae filled with clear yellow fluid, which rupture and form thin brown crusts, predominantly on the trunk and upper extremities. BI is caused by the exfoliative toxin A produced by S. aureus and is mostly seen in children 2–6 years of age. In severe cases, toxins and bacteria released into the blood system may cause fever in addition to the typical skin findings. Predisposing factors for BI include warm and humid climates, unsanitary living conditions, poor personal hygiene, disruption of the skin barrier (e.g., due to trauma or diseases such as scabies or atopic dermatitis), and immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection). First-line treatment options include oral antibiotic treatment with first-generation cephalosporins (e.g, cephalexin) and dicloxacillin. A very rare but life-threatening complication of BI is staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which is characterized by systemic spread of exfoliative toxin A and the resultant widespread desquamation of epidermal skin and signs of shock.

See “Overview of blistering diseases” table.

Key learning point: Bullous impetigo is a highly contagious pediatric skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus, presenting with flaccid bullae and thin brown crusts, most commonly on the trunk and upper extremities.

Nonbullous impetigo may be caused by Staphylococcus aureus and/or Streptococcus pyogenes and typically manifests with painless, nonpruritic, honey-colored crusts without bullae (see “Most common manifestations of impetigo” table).
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles, some of which have already ruptured and formed brown crusts, are visible on the gluteal region of this infant. The lesions in bullous impetigo are easily confused with the polymorphic rash of secondary syphilis.

C) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) is characterized by areas of pruritic excoriations and vesicles that affect the extensor surfaces of the knees, elbows, buttocks, and back. This patient's bullae and crusts manifest on his chest. Moreover, DH is uncommon in children and is typically associated with celiac disease.
Image Description:

There is an erythematous, grouped, papulovesicular rash with excoriations on the extensor surface of the shoulder.

This finding, in combination with pruritus, is consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) can manifest with large pruritic bullae that eventually rupture and form crusts. However, the bullae in BP are tense rather than flaccid and are typically distributed on the palms, soles, lower legs, groin, and axillae, not the chest. In addition, BP has a prodromal stage characterized by urticarial lesions that occurs weeks to months before blistering. Lastly, although in rare cases BP can develop in children, it most commonly manifests in individuals > 60 years of age.
Image Description:

Lateral aspect of the left knee

Multiple, ring-shaped lesions with reddish-yellow crusting and tense blisters on an erythematous base are visible.

These findings are suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. Definitive diagnosis requires immunofluorescence.

E) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) can manifest with flaccid bullae filled with clear fluid on the upper body that can rupture and form crusts. However, blisters in PV are nonpruritic and usually first develop on the oral mucosa. Although PV can develop in children, it most commonly affects individuals aged 40–60 years.
Image Description:

Scalp of an older adult

An ulcerated lesion (approx. 1–2 cm) with significant crusting around the irregular border is visible. The center of the lesion is eroded and shows a shiny surface with mild hemorrhage.

These findings are consistent with skin lesions in pemphigus vulgaris.
questions.hint: This patient has a very common and highly contagious pediatric skin disease, which is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents with a facial rash that developed abruptly during the past 48 hours and has been slightly tender to the touch. The patient has been afebrile and has no associated systemic symptoms. He has no significant medical history and no recent unusual exposures. Skin examination reveals multiple moist erythematous lesions on the face with overlying crust (figure); no vesicles or bullous lesions are evident. The rest of the examination is normal. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a systemic glucocorticoid that is not indicated in cases of superficial skin infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is indicated for cases of herpetic infection. Although a herpetic infection could also manifest with honey-colored crusting, the crust usually overlies erythematous papules or papulovesicles in a group array.

C) INCORRECT:

The systemic antibiotic doxycycline is not indicated for an immunocompetent patient with limited impetigo. Indications for systemic antibiotic therapy in impetigo include immunosuppression, extensive skin involvement, bullous disease, and membership in a cohort with multiple affected individuals.

D) INCORRECT:

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s rash — characterized by localized areas of honey-colored crusting that is loosely adhered to the face — is highly characteristic of impetigo, a contagious, bacterial infection of the superficial epidermis. Impetigo is often spread in warm, humid environments or in close, crowded quarters. The lesions of impetigo may begin as papules and progress over several days to form vesicles, pustules, and eventually a characteristic layer of adherent, golden crust. The crust usually involves the face, extremities, or both and can be itchy or painful.

Other common causes of honey-colored crusting include herpes viral infections and allergic contact dermatitis. Like impetigo, both of these conditions can also manifest with vesicles and bullae. Bacterial and viral cultures — or polymerase-chain-reaction testing for herpes simplex virus or varicella zoster virus — should be performed in cases of diagnostic uncertainty. In this patient, the absence of grouped vesicles makes herpetic disease unlikely. The location and distribution of lesions are also less concerning for herpetic infection; herpes simplex viral infection typically affects the lips, oropharynx, peri-oral area, and (infrequently) the nares, whereas varicella-zoster virus infection would manifest in a dermatomal pattern. Allergic contact dermatitis is less likely than impetigo in this patient given his lack of recent unusual exposures.

Coverage of methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) should be strongly considered for patients who live in areas with high rates of community-acquired MRSA. Topical mupirocin and retapamulin both offer staphylococcal and streptococcal coverage and are widely used as first-line agents for impetigo. Other topical antibiotics, such as clindamycin, provide only staphylococcal coverage. Topical disinfectants alone do not provide adequate treatment. Additional recommended skin-care measures include gentle removal of the crusting with soap and a washcloth.

Key learning point: First-line treatment for a limited area of nonbullous impetigo in an immunocompetent individual consists of topical antibiotic ointment.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office because of a nonpruritic rash on his face that began 5 days ago. It started as a bug bite on his chin that then developed into small pustules with surrounding redness. He has not yet received any routine childhood vaccinations. Physical examination shows small, clustered lesions with gold crusts along the lower lip and chin and submandibular lymphadenopathy. At a follow-up examination 2 weeks later, serum titers of anti-deoxyribonuclease B and anti-streptolysin O antibodies are elevated. Which of the following is the most likely complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a severe systemic inflammatory reaction to bacterial exotoxins acting as superantigens. S. aureus is the most common causative agent, although streptococcal TSS may occur in the setting of infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococci. Although both pathogens can cause impetigo, TSS is an exceedingly rare complication. Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome is most commonly associated with prolonged tampon use (over several days) and, to a lesser extent, post-surgical or wound infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis is a rare, immune-mediated condition that manifests with a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis 1–4 weeks after an enteric or genitourinary bacterial infection. It typically occurs in genetically predisposed young adults and is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Group A streptococcal infections such as impetigo are not known to trigger reactive arthritis.

C) CORRECT:

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a common complication of impetigo and may occur in response to an infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci. It is caused by immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane, which triggers complement activation and subsequent destruction of the glomeruli (type III hypersensitivity reaction). PSGN typically arises 1–6 weeks following infection, with features of nephritic syndrome, such as hematuria, edema, and hypertension.

Further complications of group A streptococcal infections include rheumatic fever and scarlet fever. Although scarlet fever occurs in very rare cases after streptococcal skin infections such as impetigo, both conditions are typically only associated with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

D) INCORRECT:

Orchitis is a typical complication of viral mumps infection. Given the lack of vaccinations, this child is at increased risk of contracting mumps. However, mumps classically manifests with inflammation and swelling of the salivary glands and is not associated with a rash. However, orchitis is not a known complication of infections with S. aureus or group A streptococci such as impetigo.

E) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis is a complication of infection with toxin-producing strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Diphtheria initially manifests with fever, malaise, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy, but cutaneous manifestations such as nonhealing sores may also be seen. Although this child's lack of vaccinations puts him at risk for infection with C. diphtheriae, his presentation and elevated antibody titers are inconsistent with diphtheria.
questions.hint: This child's gold-crusted facial lesions are consistent with impetigo, a cutaneous infection that may be caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, or coinfection with both pathogens. The elevated anti-deoxyribonuclease B (anti-DNase B) and anti-streptolysin O (ASO) antibody titers indicate that the causal pathogen was S. pyogenes.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with a skin rash. The rash appeared a few days after he scraped his face while playing and has spread since then. They are several erythematous lesions over the face and trunk. He has been scratching them occasionally, and a few new lesions have appeared near the corner of his mouth. His mother notes mild drainage and reports a low-grade fever earlier in the week. Examination reveals tender preauricular and axillary lymph nodes (see image).
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Impetigo manifests as a superficial bacterial skin infection, often seen in children. It typically follows minor skin trauma, such as a scrape, which allows bacteria like Staphylococcus aureus or Group A Streptococcus to enter. The progression from erythematous, swollen lesions to thick, yellowish crusts is characteristic. Autoinoculation through scratching can lead to additional lesions. Mild systemic signs, such as low-grade fever and tender regional lymphadenopathy, support an infectious etiology consistent with impetigo.

Key learning point: Impetigo is a common bacterial skin infection in children that often starts at the site of a minor skin injury and can spread, presenting with red sores that form a yellowish-brown crust and may be associated with swollen lymph nodes.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

B) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis presents as annular, scaly lesions with a raised border and central clearing, not thick, yellowish crusts. It develops gradually and lacks systemic signs like fever or lymphadenopathy. The temporal link between trauma and lesions suggests a bacterial, not fungal, cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus infections present with clusters of vesicular lesions on an erythematous base, often with prodromal symptoms. The thick, yellowish crusts and lesion evolution from trauma suggest bacterial colonization rather than viral infection. Lesions from herpes simplex are typically painful and grouped.

D) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis presents with pruritic, sometimes vesicular, rashes due to irritant or allergen exposure. It rarely forms thick, yellowish crusts. The presence of fever and lymphadenopathy indicates an infectious process, not an allergic reaction.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the Pediatric Clinic by his mother with a two-day history of multiple small lesions on his face. The lesions began as erythematous macules that evolved into pustules and then ruptured to form patches with a thick, golden crust. He denies itching, and there is no fever or other systemic complaints. He has a history of mild eczema. Physical examination shows irregularly shaped, shallow erosions with a golden crust, primarily around the mouth. Regional lymph nodes are not enlarged. The family denies recent insect bites.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erysipelas is characterized by rapidly spreading, well-demarcated, raised erythematous plaques, often with systemic symptoms like fever. The absence of fever, pain, and the presence of crusted erosions rather than firm plaques make erysipelas unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis presents with an intensely pruritic, erythematous rash, often with vesicles or linear patterns. The absence of pruritus and the evolution from macules to pustules with golden crusts suggest a bacterial infection rather than a contact-mediated reaction.

C) CORRECT:

Impetigo is a superficial bacterial infection primarily caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes. It commonly affects children and manifests with lesions that begin as erythematous macules, evolve into vesicles or pustules, and rupture to form thin, golden crusts. The absence of systemic symptoms and the lesion distribution around the mouth are consistent with nonbullous impetigo. Children with eczema have a compromised skin barrier, increasing susceptibility to bacterial infections. The progression from erythema to crust formation aligns with the pathophysiology of impetigo, confirming the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Impetigo is a common superficial bacterial skin infection in children, characterized by non-itchy lesions, often with honey-colored crusts, and typically without systemic symptoms like fever.

D) INCORRECT:

Tinea faciei, a dermatophyte infection, presents as annular, scaly plaques with a raised border and central clearing. The rapid evolution from macules to pustules with golden crusts is inconsistent with tinea, which typically has a chronic course with scaling and mild pruritus.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with a rash around his nose and mouth. It began with small, red, itchy spots and over the past two days, developed into clusters of fluid-filled blisters that ruptured, leaving a golden-yellow crust. He appears healthy and has no significant medical history. Physical examination reveals superficial lesions with minimal surrounding redness.

Temperature
37.1°C

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus infections present with grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, often painful and ulcerative, not forming a honey-colored crust. Systemic symptoms like fever and mucosal involvement are common, which are absent in this presentation.

B) CORRECT:

Impetigo manifests in children with small, red, itchy macules that progress to fluid-filled vesicles, which rupture to form golden-yellow crusts. This condition commonly affects the perioral region and is a superficial skin infection. Staphylococcus aureus is often the causative organism, producing exfoliative toxins that disrupt intercellular connections in the epidermis, leading to bullae and crusting. The absence of systemic symptoms, such as fever, supports the diagnosis of a localized, superficial bacterial infection.

Key learning point: Honey-colored crusted lesions in children are characteristic of impetigo, most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

C) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis is characterized by localized inflammation with well-demarcated erythema and edema, sometimes with vesicles, but does not typically evolve into clusters of vesicles with golden-yellow crusts. The absence of exposure to an irritant or allergen further reduces the likelihood of this diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Erysipelas presents as a rapidly spreading, well-demarcated, erythematous, and indurated plaque, often with systemic symptoms like fever. The lesions are intensely red and painful with raised borders, unlike the superficial vesicles and golden-yellow crusts seen here.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with small, fluid-filled lesions around his nose and mouth that rapidly ruptured, leaving thick, golden-colored crusts. He had mild nasal congestion a few days before the lesions appeared. He complains of mild itching around the affected areas but no significant pain. There is no lymphadenopathy.

Temperature
37.2°C

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus can cause vesicular lesions in the perioral region, but these are typically painful, grouped vesicles that progress to ulcerations rather than forming thick, golden crusts. Primary herpes simplex infections in children often present with systemic symptoms such as fever and significant discomfort, which are absent here. Additionally, recurrent herpes labialis usually localizes at the vermillion border of the lips, contrasting with the broader perinasal and perioral distribution seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin reaction to an allergen or irritant, presenting with well-demarcated erythema, edema, and sometimes pruritus. The described lesion morphology—small, fluid-filled vesicles that rapidly rupture and form thick, golden crusts—suggests an infectious etiology. The perioral distribution without a clear history of exposure to a triggering substance and preceding viral-like symptoms are inconsistent with contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Tinea corporis, a dermatophyte infection, presents as well-circumscribed, annular lesions with an erythematous, scaly border and central clearing. It does not produce small, fluid-filled lesions that rapidly rupture to form thick, golden crusts. The localization of lesions around the nose and mouth and the evolution from vesicular lesions to crusting are more consistent with a bacterial skin infection rather than a fungal process.

D) CORRECT:

Impetigo manifests with small vesiculobullous lesions that rapidly evolve into thick, golden crusts, characteristic of this superficial bacterial skin infection. It is common in children and often follows minor upper respiratory infections, which can disrupt the skin barrier and facilitate bacterial colonization by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. The limited systemic manifestations and localized distribution around the face are typical of impetigo, where involvement remains primarily confined to the epidermis with a modest inflammatory response.

Key learning point: Impetigo is a common bacterial skin infection in children characterized by honey-colored crusts following vesicular lesions, often caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to your clinic with a 3-day history of a pruritic skin rash on his chest. On examination, there are multiple vesicles and flaccid bullae containing clear, yellow fluid, along with ruptured bullae surrounded by thin brown crusts. Examination of the oral mucosa is normal. Complete blood count results are within the reference range. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bullous pemphigoid (BP) can manifest with large pruritic bullae that eventually rupture and form crusts. However, the bullae in BP are tense rather than flaccid and are typically distributed on the palms, soles, lower legs, groin, and axillae, not the chest. In addition, BP has a prodromal stage characterized by urticarial lesions that occurs weeks to months before blistering. Lastly, although in rare cases BP can develop in children, it most commonly manifests in individuals > 60 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Although erythema multiforme (EM) may manifest with pruritic skin lesions, the skin findings are characteristically of variable morphology (erythematous macules, papules, vesicles, target lesions with central necrosis). Moreover, the rash first affects the back of the hands and feet before spreading proximally to the rest of the body. Finally, EM is most common in adults 20–40 years of age and is usually associated with infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus, Mycoplasma pneumoniae) and/or the use of medications (e.g., barbiturates, NSAIDs, phenytoin).

Bullous impetigo (BI) is characterized by vesicles that grow to form large flaccid bullae filled with clear yellow fluid, which rupture and form thin brown crusts, predominantly on the trunk and upper extremities. BI is caused by the exfoliative toxin A produced by S. aureus and is mostly seen in children 2–6 years of age. In severe cases, toxins and bacteria released into the blood system may cause fever in addition to the typical skin findings. Predisposing factors for BI include warm and humid climates, unsanitary living conditions, poor personal hygiene, disruption of the skin barrier (e.g., due to trauma or diseases such as scabies or atopic dermatitis), and immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection). First-line treatment options include oral antibiotic treatment with first-generation cephalosporins (e.g, cephalexin) and dicloxacillin. A very rare but life-threatening complication of BI is staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, which is characterized by systemic spread of exfoliative toxin A and the resultant widespread desquamation of epidermal skin and signs of shock.

See “Overview of blistering diseases” table.

Key learning point: Bullous impetigo is a superficial skin infection in young children caused by Staphylococcus aureus, presenting with flaccid bullae and thin brown crusts, typically on the trunk and extremities.

Nonbullous impetigo may be caused by Staphylococcus aureus and/or Streptococcus pyogenes and typically manifests with painless, nonpruritic, honey-colored crusts without bullae (see “Most common manifestations of impetigo” table).
Image Description:

Multiple vesicles, some of which have already ruptured and formed brown crusts, are visible on the gluteal region of this infant. The lesions in bullous impetigo are easily confused with the polymorphic rash of secondary syphilis.

D) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris (PV) can manifest with flaccid bullae filled with clear fluid on the upper body that can rupture and form crusts. However, blisters in PV are nonpruritic and usually first develop on the oral mucosa. Although PV can develop in children, it most commonly affects individuals aged 40–60 years.

E) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) is characterized by areas of pruritic excoriations and vesicles that affect the extensor surfaces of the knees, elbows, buttocks, and back. This patient's bullae and crusts manifest on his chest. Moreover, DH is uncommon in children and is typically associated with celiac disease.
questions.hint: This patient has a very common and highly contagious pediatric skin disease, which is caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

E) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is a systemic glucocorticoid that is not indicated in cases of superficial skin infection.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic because of a nonpruritic facial rash that began 5 days ago. The rash started as a bug bite on his chin and progressed to small pustules with surrounding redness. He has not received any routine childhood vaccinations. On examination, there are small, clustered lesions with golden crusts along the lower lip and chin, as well as submandibular lymphadenopathy. At a follow-up visit 2 weeks later, his serum titers of anti-deoxyribonuclease B and anti-streptolysin O antibodies are elevated. Which one of the following is the most likely complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Orchitis is a typical complication of viral mumps infection. Given the lack of vaccinations, this child is at increased risk of contracting mumps. However, mumps classically manifests with inflammation and swelling of the salivary glands and is not associated with a rash. However, orchitis is not a known complication of infections with S. aureus or group A streptococci such as impetigo.

B) INCORRECT:

Reactive arthritis is a rare, immune-mediated condition that manifests with a triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis 1–4 weeks after an enteric or genitourinary bacterial infection. It typically occurs in genetically predisposed young adults and is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. Group A streptococcal infections such as impetigo are not known to trigger reactive arthritis.

C) CORRECT:

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a common complication of impetigo and may occur in response to an infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci. It is caused by immune complex deposition within the glomerular basement membrane, which triggers complement activation and subsequent destruction of the glomeruli (type III hypersensitivity reaction). PSGN typically arises 1–6 weeks following infection, with features of nephritic syndrome, such as hematuria, edema, and hypertension.

Further complications of group A streptococcal infections include rheumatic fever and scarlet fever. Although scarlet fever occurs in very rare cases after streptococcal skin infections such as impetigo, both conditions are typically only associated with streptococcal tonsillopharyngitis.

Key learning point: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a classic complication of impetigo caused by nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

D) INCORRECT:

Myocarditis is a complication of infection with toxin-producing strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. Diphtheria initially manifests with fever, malaise, sore throat, and cervical lymphadenopathy, but cutaneous manifestations such as nonhealing sores may also be seen. Although this child's lack of vaccinations puts him at risk for infection with C. diphtheriae, his presentation and elevated antibody titers are inconsistent with diphtheria.

E) INCORRECT:

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a severe systemic inflammatory reaction to bacterial exotoxins acting as superantigens. S. aureus is the most common causative agent, although streptococcal TSS may occur in the setting of infection with group A β-hemolytic streptococci. Although both pathogens can cause impetigo, TSS is an exceedingly rare complication. Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome is most commonly associated with prolonged tampon use (over several days) and, to a lesser extent, post-surgical or wound infections.
questions.hint: This child's gold-crusted facial lesions are consistent with impetigo, a cutaneous infection that may be caused by Streptococcus pyogenes, Staphylococcus aureus, or coinfection with both pathogens. The elevated anti-deoxyribonuclease B (anti-DNase B) and anti-streptolysin O (ASO) antibody titers indicate that the causal pathogen was S. pyogenes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the clinic with a 4-day history of a rash on his face. The rash began after he nicked himself while shaving, initially presenting as small red bumps around his nose and upper lip that then developed into small blisters which ruptured. He denies fever, chills, or other systemic symptoms. His medical history is unremarkable. He is an avid weightlifter. On examination, there are multiple discrete erosions with overlying thick, yellowish, adherent crusts in the perinasal and perioral areas. There is no surrounding cellulitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clotrimazole is a topical antifungal medication used to treat dermatophyte infections (tinea) or candidiasis. This patient's clinical presentation, particularly the progression from vesicles to thick, yellowish crusts, is characteristic of a bacterial infection (impetigo), not a fungal one. Antifungal therapy would be ineffective.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral cephalexin is an appropriate treatment for impetigo because it provides excellent coverage for both S. aureus and S. pyogenes. However, this antibiotic is reserved for patients with numerous lesions, deep tissue involvement, systemic signs of infection such as fever, or in cases in which alternative agents have been unsuccessful.

C) CORRECT:

Non-bullous impetigo is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. For localized, uncomplicated impetigo without systemic symptoms, topical antibiotics are the first-line treatment. Mupirocin is highly effective against both S. aureus (including many methicillin-resistant S. aureus strains) and S. pyogenes, making it the preferred agent. This approach minimizes systemic side effects and the risk of promoting antibiotic resistance compared to oral therapies.
Image Description:

Confluent scabbed erosions and honey-colored crusts are visible in the perioral region. This appearance is typical of impetigo, which, in this patient, developed secondary to preexisting eczema and immunosuppression caused by HIV infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline provides coverage for methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) and is used for certain skin and soft tissue infections. However, it is not a first-line agent for uncomplicated impetigo. Doxycycline is typically indicated when community MRSA prevalence is high or cultures confirm infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacitracin is a widely available over-the-counter topical antibiotic. However, it is not recommended for treating impetigo due to high rates of bacterial resistance, particularly among S. aureus isolates. Furthermore, bacitracin is a frequent cause of allergic contact dermatitis, which can complicate the clinical picture. More effective agents are indicated for this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of papules progressing to vesicles that rupture and form thick, honey-colored crusts is typical of non-bullous impetigo. The choice of therapy depends on the extent of the disease.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of small, superficial lesions at the corners of his mouth that have formed distinct honey-colored crusts. He reports mild itching but denies pain or fever. He has no history of similar lesions and is otherwise healthy and up to date on immunizations. Physical examination reveals two well-demarcated crusted lesions without surrounding erythema or exudation. The remainder of his skin exam is unremarkable. Gram stain of a swab from one lesion shows gram-positive cocci in clusters.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Impetigo, a superficial bacterial skin infection common in children, is often caused by Staphylococcus aureus, as indicated by gram-positive cocci in clusters. The presentation of localized, honey-colored crusted lesions around the mouth is typical of nonbullous impetigo. Topical mupirocin ointment is the preferred treatment for localized impetigo due to its targeted action against the bacteria, high efficacy, and minimal systemic exposure. This approach expedites resolution and reduces the risk of antibiotic resistance associated with systemic antibiotics.

Key learning point: Impetigo, a common bacterial skin infection in children, is best treated with antibiotics, as it is typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral cephalexin is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including Staphylococcus aureus, and is used for widespread infections or systemic involvement. This child has localized lesions without systemic signs, making topical treatment preferable to avoid unnecessary systemic exposure and potential adverse effects.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V targets penicillin-sensitive streptococci but is ineffective against Staphylococcus aureus, which often produces beta-lactamases. The gram-positive cocci in clusters suggest Staphylococcus aureus, and the localized nature of the lesions favors topical over systemic treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone cream reduces inflammation but does not address bacterial infections. The child's lesions and gram-positive cocci in clusters indicate impetigo, requiring antibacterial treatment. Hydrocortisone may suppress local immune responses, potentially worsening the infection.
